case_vignette:
A 22-year-old woman complains of an itchy rash on her leg for 4 weeks. She is a collegiate swimmer and had a prior ringworm infection during her freshman year. She has been using over-the-counter antifungal cream for the past 3 weeks with no relief. Multiple round, erythematous, scaling lesions are present on her right leg, some of which are vesicular and weeping. Potassium hydroxide (KOH) test is negative for a dermatophytic infection. The patient is a college student and is otherwise healthy.
The patient is a 22-year-old college student who complains of an itchy rash on their leg for 4 weeks. They are a collegiate athlete and had a prior ringworm infection during their freshman year. They have been using over-the-counter antifungal cream for the past 3 weeks with no relief. Multiple round, erythematous, scaling lesions are present on their right leg, some of which are vesicular and weeping. Potassium hydroxide (KOH) test is negative for a dermatophytic infection. The patient is otherwise healthy.

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have an itchy rash on my leg that has been there for 4 weeks.
Have you noticed any changes in color or spreading of the rash since it appeared?
Yes, the rash has multiple round, red, scaly lesions on my right leg. Some of these lesions are also blistering and oozing.
Do you have a history of allergies or asthma?
No, I do not have a history of allergies or asthma.
Have you been in contact with any new skincare products, detergents, plants, or animals recently before the rash appeared?
No, I have not been in contact with any new skincare products, detergents, plants, or animals recently before the rash appeared.
Have you experienced similar skin issues in the past?
Yes, I had a ringworm infection during my freshman year.
Final Diagnosis: Tinea corporis.

The rash consists of multiple round, red, scaly lesions on the patient’s right leg, with some lesions additionally blistering and oozing. The patient denies any history of allergies or asthma and has not been in contact with any new skincare products, detergents, plants, or animals prior to the onset of the rash. However, the patient does have a history of a ringworm infection during their freshman year.
